ygData.subject: Re: Species stagnation
ygData.msgSnippet: Derek, Thank you very much for your interest in my domain, let me explain more specifically what I am doing and what I have done already. Firstly, this is for

Subject: Re: Species stagnation
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=216215274
X-Yahoo-Profile: gerbopel


Derek,

Thank you very much for your interest in my domain, let me explain
more specifically what I am doing and what I have done already.

Firstly, this is for an Honours Dissertation in Computer Games
Technology, at the University of Abertay in Scotland.  I've been doing
research for it for over a month now so I feel that I have a good
grounding in the theory... it's the implementation that's troubling me.

So, here is a screenshot of the scenario:
http://www.redcrocodile.net/test/nolog/CatAndMouse.jpg

The cat is red, the mouse is yellow.  The cat has 16 inputs:

0-3: Distance to walls in U,R,D,L
4-7: Proximity to mouse in U,R,D,L (-1.0 for no sight)
8-11: Direction heading of mouse is: U,R,D,L (-1.0 or +1.0)
12-15: Measure of how long since walking on tiles in U,R,D,L

The cat can only see through LOS.  There are five outputs of the cat:

0 - Move Up
1 - Move Right
2 - Move Down
3 - Move Left
4 - Make Sound

The sounds can be ignored at this point.  If no direction value is >=
0.9 then the cat stays put.  Otherwise whichever direction value is
highest, the cat goes that way.  This is processed every game tick.

Each agent (cat and mouse) can move one tile per turn.  They both get
one turn per game tick.  The cat goes first.

I am taking an incremental approach to learning here so these are the
four scenarios that have been tackled to this point:

A) Static mouse.  The cat has LOS to the mouse and must go to him. 
Various distances and locations to walls tested.  Evolved successfully.

B) Mouse moving away from cat (3 tiles max).  The cat has LOS to the
mouse and the mouse moves away from the cat but does not reach an
intersection.  Various distances and locations to walls tested. 
Evolved successfully.

C) Mouse moving towards cat.  Identical to B but mouse runs straight
at the cat.  Evolved successfully.

D) Mouse goes out of sight (4 tiles max).  Mouse starts in an
intersection (screenshot above) and on his first move will go out of
sight from the cat.  With a 4 move maximum you will notice that the
mouse will never be able to turn at another intersection.  The cat
receives the direction vector of the mouse for the frame after it
dissapeared (if he could see) but otherwise all he has is anything
left in his memory.  Obviously for this test to be successful, some
recurrent connections must be developed.  I have boiled this final
scenario down to the simplest form possible for memory (screenshot). 
Nothing is randomized, the start positions (for each scenario) are
loaded from a scenario file and the directions that the mouse takes
are alternated so the cat gets to try each intersection with the mouse
going RIGHT, then LEFT.

I do scenario D for directions: U, R (screenshot), D, L and not a
single agent has managed to complete all four directions successfully.
 The directions that are done properly are obviously not because they
"remembered" where the mouse was but because some random search
pattern happens to bring them to the right location, thus it works for
some but not for others.  The map layout is inducive to such behaviour
but I felt it was important to simplify everything as much as possible.

The way I work the evolution is first I evolve on scenario A.  Then I
combine scenario A with scenario B and evolve on both of those (so an
agent is tested on both).  Then I combine scenario C with scenario A
and B.  And so on.

I have fantastic success with A,B,C.  I've tried every setting in the
world for evolution now (% add link, % add neuron, % toggle link
enabled, etc...) and A usually takes the longest (40 starting pairs)
by finding a solution by G20.  10+ solutions by G50.  B usually finds
upwards of 20 solutions by G28.  C usually finds a perfect solution
within the first 1 or 2 generations.  10+ found by G13.

I've run D up to generation 1500 and out of a perfect 3197 the closest
a cat has come is around 2900.  Again, that is strictly through
"random" searching that happens to pay off sometimes and looks
atrocious.  For example, some cats simply go down all the time - this
gets them some payoffs as a bunch of the start pairs have the mouse
placed down from the cat.

My most recent aborted attempt at scenario D can be found here:
http://www.redcrocodile.net/test/nolog/CatAndMouseLog.txt

Each line is as follows:

{Timestamp} Generation#(#since improv), # Of Spec, AvgFit, TopFit (ID)

So when the cats get to scenario D, they know how to do everything
except remember where they last saw the mouse.  If they can see the
mouse, they can catch him.  I keep scenario A,B,C in the comparison to
ensure that a method for solving D doesn't destroy the methods for
solving A,B,C.

I think that answered all of your questions about the situation.  If I
missed anything out, let me know.

Thank you very much for your continued help, it is greatly
appreciated.  I was feeling pretty distraught today (been doing these
experiments for 8 straight days now and don't have much to show for it
yet) but I am not giving up yet!

At the moment I am sending a fully connected, 5 hidden neuron,
recurrent NN through scenarios A,B,C and D to see if indeed this is
possible.  I am only evolving the weights and it has flown through A,B
and C and is now working on D.  G94 has F2689 so far.  Not bad.

Many thanks,
Mike
